TIONG BAHRU
(Public garden)


    The following Question stood in the name of Madam Chan Choy Siong -

    1. To ask the Minister for Law and National Development whether work has commenced on the proposed public garden at Tiong Bahru Road for which funds have been approved; and when the project will be completed.

    Mr Speaker: Madam Chan Choy Siong.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang): Question No. 1.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Sir, work on the public garden at Tiong Bahru commenced in February this year and is expected to be completed by the end of January next year.

Column: 522

SINGAPORE - GARDEN CITY
(Projects carried out)


    2. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) what is the extent of the projects carried out since 1st January, 1968, towards making Singapore a garden city; (b) if he will give details of (i) the areas where trees and plants have been planted; and (ii) the number and location of new gardens developed; and (c) whether there are any plans in hand to construct fountains in every constituency.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, since January 1968 about 13,000 trees have been planted at about 240 roads and sites. These trees, together with those planted last year, bring the number of trees planted as at October 1968 to about 28,000 at about 380 roads and

Column: 523

sites. The sites include 21 traffic islands, 20 road circuses and 23 Government buildings.

    In the development of the "floral mile" along Bukit Timah Road, ten nurseries and a drive-in restaurant have been constructed. Nine of the nurseries and the restaurant block have already been let.

    The floodlighting of King George V Park has been completed at a cost of about $26,880. Lighting is also being provided at several children's play grounds, e.g., the Hindoo Road children's playground, the Kampong Wak Tanjong children's playground and the children's playground between Lorongs 38 and 40. Floodlights have been provided in the Botanic Gardens which are now open to the public nightly till 10 p.m.

    The first phase of the development of Tiong Bahru Regional Park with an area of about seven acres has been completed. This involved landscaping and the planting of trees and shrubs. The second phase which includes the provision of lighting, benches and other facilities will be completed soon.

    Public amenities have also been provided at Mount Washington and the site has been landscaped and trees and shrubs planted.

    There are no plans to construct fountains in every constituency.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT
BOARD
(Allocation of flats nearest to applicants' places of work)


    3. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board what steps are being taken by the Board to ensure that applicants for the Board's flats are allocated flats in estates that are nearest to their places of work.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, at the time of registration, applicants are asked to state their choice of localities and order of preference. Allocations

Column: 524

are made accordingly and wherever possible allocations are made of flats in estates of choice. However, difficulties a rise when applicants begin to apply for flats in housing estates that are already fully occupied.

    There is also the difficulty of more popular areas where, because of land limitations, only a few blocks are built and the supply cannot meet the demand. Under such circumstances, the applicants will have to wait for casual vacancies which are few and far between, and they have to wait for a considerable time.

    On occasion, the Board allocates to such applicants new flats that may not be too far from the locality of the applicants' choice, but often such allocations are rejected.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT
BOARD
(Policy on applications for transfer to larger or smaller flats)


    4. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Law and National Development Board if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board (a) what is the present policy in regard to applications from existing tenants for transfer to larger or smaller flats; (b) how many such applications were out standing on 31st October, 1968; and (c) whether there has been any delay in dealing with the applications and the reasons for the delay.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, applications from existing tenants for transfer to other flats are not given priority because there is a larger number of applicants waiting to be allocated accommodation. However, transfers are permitted when the applicant is suffering some hardship, e.g., overcrowding or due to financial circumstances.

    On 31st October, 1968, about 5,309 applicants had been registered for transfers, most of whom had been made offers by the Board which they hail rejected. In the result, there has been no delay in dealing with transfer applications.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister consider transfers within the estate whenever there are vacancies available, as I understand these vacancies are normally reserved for rehousing dispossessed families?

    Mr Barker: Sir, if such vacancies are reserved for resettlement cases who are given priority, then transfers within the estate will not be approved unless it is an exchange between two tenants who desire to exchange accommodation.

TOA PAYOH HOUSING ESTATE
(Flats for rent)


    5. Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board what measures are being taken by the Board to make available more flats in the Toa Payoh Housing Estate for rental to applicants who are in no position to participate in the Board's "Home Ownership Scheme".

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, currently about 9,000 units of flats have been completed and occupied while another 8,000 units are under construction in Toa Payoh Housing Estate. It is the Government's policy to sell as many flats as possible, but notwithstanding this, approximately 40 per cent of the flats in Toa Payoh will be set aside for rental to accommodate those applicants who are unable to participate in the home ownership scheme.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT
BOARD FLATS
(Revision of limits of incomes for eligibility to purchase)


    6. Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board whether the Board will consider revising the limits of individual and total family incomes, at present $800 and $1,000, respectively, for eligibility to purchase

Column: 526

the Board's flats, in the light of the recent amendment to the Central Provident Fund Ordinance raising the maximum of contributions to the Fund to encourage workers to become home owners.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, Government's policy in respect of the home ownership scheme is to limit the income level of the applicant to $800 per month in the case of individual incomes and $1,000 per month in the case of joint family incomes. Those earning above these limits are considered to be reasonably well off and their housing needs should be catered for by private developers. The income restrictions, however, do not apply to sitting tenants who may wish to use their Central Provident Fund balances to purchase the flats they now occupy.

    With the recent implementation of the amendments to the Central Provident Fund legislation and the reduction in the deposit requirements for the purchase of flats, more families in the lower income group will be able to purchase a home of their own. For the time being, therefore, the Government feels that it should not revise the income limits to which I referred.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT
BOARD
(Eviction of tenants)


    10. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board whether tenants are, as a rule, evicted from the Board's flats for contravening any of the tenancy conditions or being in arrears in rent; and (b) whether he will issue a directive to the Board to adopt a more reasonable attitude in the eviction of tenants.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development)(In Mandarin): Sir, normally the Housing and Development Board, in dealing with tenants who have infringed any conditions of rental or are is arrears in

Column: 529

rent, will carry out investigations into these cases before action is taken. So far, the measures taken in dealing with these cases have been very reasonable. I am of the view that my Ministry does not have reason to believe that it is necessary to ask the Board to adopt a more reasonable attitude in dealing with these cases.

    When a tenant contravenes any tenancy conditions or is in arrears in rent, the Board do not usually evict him immediately. As usual, the Board will issue a notice of warning to him and ask him to comply with the necessary requirements within 10 days. If after receiving this notice the tenant still persists in contravening the said regulations, then the Board will ask him to move out from his flat.

    Mr Lee Teck Him (Ulu Pandan)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in my opinion, there should be changes in the Board's regulations. For instance, when a family is starving, how do you expect it to pay the rent?

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Lee, there are altogether 18 questions on the Order Paper, and if you have any criticism to make on this point, I suggest that you speak tomorrow in the Estimates debate on the Minister's salary. Do you have a supplementary question now?

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, I merely want to say that the action taken should depend on the merits of individual cases and should also take into account the financial condition of the tenants. The regulations should also be amended and harsh action should not be taken to force the tenants to move out. Does the Parliamentary Secretary not agree that as we are a democratic country we

should not therefore adopt an imperialistic attitude?

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I will clarify certain points raised by the Member for Ulu Pandan on the action taken by the Housing and Development Board to evict tenants who have engaged in gambling and also those who have bought their own houses.

    The Member should understand that the flats rented out by the Housing and Development Board are meant only for dwelling purposes. If they are used for any other purposes, the Housing and Development Board will take action to evict the tenants. This is expressly provided in the tenancy agreement. If the tenants of the flats have the financial means to buy their own houses, then they should give up their flats to the Housing and Development Board so that the vacated flats can be allotted to other applicants.

    On the question of tenants not being able to pay their rentals and have been notified to move out, I must explain that the Board has to collect rentals from the tenants because it is not a charitable organisation. If the tenants are in financial difficulties or are unemployed, they should seek assistance from the Social Welfare Department.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary has not given the correct answers to the questions I have raised. I was saying that we should not force a tenant to move out if he is unable to buy the flat he is occupying. I was not talking about tenants buying their own houses.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon(In Mandarin): Sir, I missed the point about tenants, not being able to buy Housing and Development Board flats. The Board has always taken a very liberal attitude' in this matter. For instance, if a tenant is unable to buy the flat he is occupying, the Board will allot him accommodation in some other housing estate. Generally, the Board will not force him to buy the flat he is occupying.

THOMSON ROAD
GENERAL HOSPITAL
(Extension of boundary to serve Jalan Kayu)


    11. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Health whether he will consider extending the boundary of the area served by the Thomson Road General Hospital to include the Constituency of Jalan Kayu in view of its nearness to that Hospital.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the area served by the Thomson Road General Hospital is periodically reviewed. Extension of the boundaries served by the hospital by taking in other constituencies, such as Jalan Kayu, will certainly be considered. But it is regretted that extension of the area served by the hospital cannot be accepted now. The hospital is relatively new and its facilities have been only gradually increased. It would be unwise if it attempts to take in a much larger area than it could properly deal with. It is better to start off with a smaller area and when staff and other facilities are increased, it can then expand its services to a wider area.

    The area served by the hospital itself is rapidly developing. The satellite town of Toa Payoh alone will have around 250,000 persons. A population of this size will sorely tax the hospital which has a total capacity of only 396 beds. The addition of other constituencies within its responsibilities will probably overwhelm it.

    If the demand for Jalan Kayu is to be met by the Thomson Road General Hospital, the other constituencies such as Nee Soon, Serangoon Gardens and Thomson which are closer and intervene between Jalan Kayu and the hospital would also have to be entertained. It is for this reason that it would not be prudent at this stage to consider extending the areas served by Thomson Road General Hospital to include the constituency of Jalan Kayu.

TAN TOCK SENG HOSPITAL
(Admission of confirmed tuberculosis cases to medical wards)


    12. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Health why confirmed tuberculosis cases are admitted to the Medical Wards in Tan Tock Seng Hospital not meant for such cases.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, there have been occasions where tuberculosis cases have been admitted to the Medical Wards in Tan Tock Seng Hospital. These were for the following reasons:

    (a) it was not known that these patients at the time of admission were suffering from tuberculosis; or

    (b) in those confirmed cases of tuberculosis, they were admitted for some other medical condition requiring investigation or treatment in a Medical Ward. It should be mentioned that the Medical Wards in other hospitals do occasionally, also for the same reasons, admit tuberculosis cases.

    The Member for Mountbatten is assured that there is no danger whatsoever to other patients or their visitors in a ward where tuberculosis cases are present. A patient suffering from tuberculosis in a hospital is under treatment and in these circumstances is not infectious. If there is a chance that he is infectious, special precautions are taken, for example, by isolation in a separate room in the same ward, and his clothes and utensils are kept separate and are carefully sterilised.

TAN TOCK SENG HOSPITAL
(Free admission to medical wards)


    13. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Health why persons who are well able to afford paying for hospitalisation have been, and are being, admitted to the Medical Wards in Tan Tock Seng Hospital admission to which is free.

Column: 533



    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, Tan Tock Seng Hospital is a free hospital. There are no paying class wards in it. Hence any patient admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital, whether to the Tuberculosis Chest or Thoracic, Surgical or Medical Wards is admitted free.

    Admissions to the Medical Wards at Tan Tock Seng Hospital are taken from the Admission Room of the Outram Road General Hospital on a roster basis. The sole criterion for admission is whether or not the patient requires admission to the hospital, and no account is taken whether or not the patient may be able to afford admission to a paying class ward, as the hospital, as mentioned previously, does not have paying class wards. But if the patients request admission to paying class wards, they are then returned for admission to the paying class wards in the Outram Road General Hospital.

    Development estimate proposals have been made to convert two wards in the hospital to accommodate paying class patients. The estimate for making the conversions has been given by the Public Works Department as costing $75,000. The cost for furniture and equipment will bring this up to about $112,000.

    Approval for conversion of these paying class wards has been just given and is included in next year's estimates, and it is the intention to effect the conversion in the very near future. These two paying class wards will be used for general medical as well as tuberculosis patients.

    There are at present four free class medical wards. When the revised ward charges are implemented, patients admitted to these medical wards will pay similar rates chargeable to those admitted to 'C' class wards in other hospitals.

GENERAL HOSPITAL -
ORTHOPAEDIC DEPARTMENT
(Particulars of cases of hand injuries)


    14. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Health (a) how many hand injuries have been recorded for treatment at the Orthop‘edic Department in the General Hospital from 1st January, 1968, to the latest convenient date; (b) how many of such injuries had been caused while the injured persons were working with machines in operation; and (c) how many of such injuries have resulted in total or partial permanent disability of the hand.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: During the period 1st January, 1968, to 30th September, 1968 - that is nine months the number of patients treated for hand injuries at the Orthop‘edic Department of the Outram Road General Hospital is 1,679.

    Of this number, a total of 289 persons were injured while working with machines in operation.

    The assessment for disability is made usually after a period of about six months since the injury. For the period January to March 1968, 51 patients -about ten per cent - of those injured had injuries resulting in total or partial permanent disablement of the hand.

PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENT
(Cleansing of completed roads in private housing estates)


    15. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Health why the Public Health Department is not undertaking the cleansing of completed roads in some private housing estates.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: It is provided under section 66 of the Local Government Integration Ordinance, 1963 -the relevant law relating to public cleansing - that the Health Authority shall cause public streets, including footpaths etc, to be swept and cleansed. Under section 67 (1) of the same

Column: 535

Ordinance, it is further provided that it is the responsibility of the owner or occupier of any premises on a private street to keep his portion of the street .and drain abutting his premises clean.

    Notwithstanding these provisions in 'the law, the Public Health Division does lake steps to do cleansing of private streets and the removal of refuse in a 'substantial number of private housing estates where the streets are still private streets. As far as departmental resources will permit, in terms of funds and labour, the Public Health Division will provide a cleansing service to private streets in housing estates which are completed and 'fully occupied. This is already being done in many areas; where it is not done, the reason is the non- availability of labour and funds.

    In many housing estates, individual houses are occupied gradually while physical construction of the estate is still in progress. More often the occupation of houses in such estates is before the issue of a certificate of fitness by the competent building authority. Because of building operations in progress in other parts of the estate, there is often all the accumulation of refuse, lumber and other material usually present in a developing estate.

    The usual practice is to require the developer to provide the maintenance and cleansing service while building operations are in progress. It will not be practical until an estate is occupied and building operations have ceased and the drains, pavements, sidewalks, etc, are properly completed before it is taken over for cleansing.

    It has, however, to be emphasised that the streets in such private housing estates and drains should, by and large, remain in a clean and sanitary state, as these often are areas with limited movement of the general public. A high standard of sanitary care by the residents will ensure that both the streets and drains are kept clean and free of refuse and filth. This, however, is not always so and the co-operation of householders is often needed to ensure this.

MOSQUITO-BORNE DISEASES
(Particulars of incidence)


    16. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Health what was the incidence of mosquito-borne diseases during the period 1st January to 30th September, 1968; and whether any distribution pattern is discernible in the incidence of such diseases.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the mosquito-borne diseases in Singapore are:

    (i) Malaria.

    (ii) Dengue and haemorrhagic fevers.

    (iii) Japanese encephalitis.

    (iv) Filariasis.

    Malaria is notifiable to the Public Health Division under the Quarantine and Prevention of Disease Ordinance; dengue and haemorrhagic fevers are not notifiable under this law, but are notified by administrative arrangements from Government hospitals and other Government institutions to the Public Health Division for follow-up. No notification is required in the cases of encephalitis and filariasis and figures are therefore not available for the period stated.

CITY CLEANSING WORKERS

    17. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Health how many complaints of rudeness by city cleansing workers towards members of the public were received by his Ministry during the period 1st January to 30th September, 1968; and what action has been taken in respect of such complaints.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: An investigation into our records as to the number of complaints of rudeness by cleansing workers (city and rural) to members of the public for the period 1st January to 30th September, 1968, was carried out and it is confirmed that no complaint was received during this period for investigation or action.

    The Operations Room established on 1st October, 1968, has also received no complaints of this nature.

HOLLAND ROAD 5 m.s.
(Construction of new market)


    18. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Health whether any provision has been or will be made for the construction of a new market at the 5th mile area in Holland Road and when construction will commence.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, no provision has been made to build a new market in the 5th mile area of Holland Road.

    A submission has been made under this Ministry's 1968 development proposals to build an extension to the existing market at Holland Village. But the proposal has been accorded low priority and no funds have so far been provided.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, who is responsible for this mistake? The former Minister for Health said that a new market would be built in the 5th mile area of Holland Road. That was long ago. Perhaps the present Minister for Health is not aware of it. I will write a formal letter to the Minister for Health inviting him to visit the area to see for himself whether a market is urgently required there.

    Mr Speaker: I do not think that calls for a reply unless the Minister wants to reply.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker. Sir, it is not that I do not sympathise with the Member for Ulu Pandan. In fact, if he had listened very carefully to the answer that I just made, my Ministry did make a submission in the 1968 Development Estimate proposals to build an extension to the existing market. But as Members know, the Minister for Finance has said that, in view of the economic stringencies, we will have to exercise some restraint with regard to some of these projects. That is why this proposal has been accorded low priority.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, may I also supply some facts to the Member for Ulu Pandan? First of all, it is not necessary

Column: 539
